model_responses: Lastly, forming an advisory committee comprising non-parent stakeholders – including business owners, retirees, artists, etcetera – offers them opportunities to contribute their unique insights while also fostering deeper connections between schools and communities they serve.

The key is that you're looking at it from multiple angles. I mean, we've got local businesses who have employees with children here, retirees who care deeply about this district because they grew up here or their kids went through the schools, folks without children but still invested in the community's future - all of them can offer valuable perspectives.  So first off, let me say social media has been helpful for us; using Facebook Live sessions where we do Q&A sessions around specific topics. It allows people to participate remotely if needed, which opens doors wider than traditional town halls. We also started partnering more closely with libraries and community centers as neutral meeting spaces so everyone feels welcome attending meetings there rather than always on school grounds. We're starting an advisory committee made entirely of non-parents/non-educators. This group meets quarterly discussing broad themes like budgeting priorities or facilities planning. These individuals bring fresh eyes to challenges while keeping focus on what matters most – student outcomes. And lastly, hosting open houses showcasing student work helps build connections between students and residents outside the immediate family circle. By engaging those not directly tied into education daily, I believe you'll find the whole community takes greater ownership over its schools.

I believe there's no doubt that engaging with the wider community is essential for building support and fostering trust between schools and their surrounding neighborhoods. Here are several strategies we could consider implementing:  Firstly, let us make sure to host town hall meetings at various locations throughout the district so as not to limit access based on location. This would allow individuals who may have an interest but do not necessarily have children attending these institutions or work within them. Secondly, it seems like having open houses specifically geared towards non-parents, retirees, local business owners etcetera might also help increase participation rates from different demographics. Thirdly, partnering up with local libraries or other public spaces where people congregate can serve as hubs of engagement since they're already well-known gathering points which foster interaction among citizens. Fourth, creating surveys online that reach out more broadly than simply those directly connected with educational establishments allows input from all corners. Fifth, hosting workshops focusing on subjects relevant to both students & the general population alike (e.g., literacy programs) serves multiple purposes: They educate while encouraging collaboration across demographic lines. Sixth, use social media platforms effectively to spread awareness regarding initiatives undertaken, invite feedback through comment sections or dedicated pages set aside for this purpose.

kateacuff.monologue: I guess I will start with this. Colleagues, I think most, you may remember that in February or February 13th, 2020 meeting, this board approved the establishment of an advisory committee on sustainability. And charged Ms. Colson and me to develop the substance of that committee. I have to confess that it fell by the wayside through much of the pandemic, but we have, Once again, met with both Rosalind Schmidt and Lindsay Snoddy on this. And we have a proposal to establish the committee, which we will, unless there's an objection, call ACES, the Advisory Committee on Environmental Sustainability. And that committee would be modeled substantially like our long-range planning committee is modeled. The mission will be largely to look at the very key areas where we can make an environmental impact in our buildings, our buses, and the education of our students and staff. It will be to coordinate with the county, which has just approved its climate action plan, And Ms. Snoddy has already reached out to Gabe Daly, who is the point person for compliance to the county's environmental plan. And he's willing to work, be a member of the committee. And we would also have a commitment to work with more broadly with regional partners such as UVA, as it turns out UVA the sustainability specialist at UVA, without prompting, reached out to me this week to talk about, to advise about a conference that I went to, webinar, on net zero schools. And so that's the whole topic. But we would propose that we work to reduce, to track or work to have our own guideposts in terms of environment sustainability. But it would require, well, why don't you do the mechanics of it, that's Colson.

kateacuff.monologue: As we all know, Dr. Haas and his cabinet are very deeply involved in putting together the funding request that will be presented to us next week. Even at this late hour, however, I propose that Dr. Haas include in his funding request to the board a five-year overview of the capital needs of our schools. The statute that requires a superintendent to make a funding request is not specific that it's limited to operating costs, and in fact, many other school divisions include both in the funding request. And I think that we ought to be in that category, that a way to elevate our capital needs, both to the supervisors, but even more so to the community is to include the needs of our capital. You've all heard me speak with some alarm that we now have about 100 classrooms in trailers. We have a very aging infrastructure. The average age of our core school is over half a century old and they're not set up in many cases for our 21st century teaching. So I guess I propose this. I would like to have a consensus up the board and an assurance from Dr. Haas that this is feasible at this late hour.

model_responses: Well I am glad that we have this opportunity tonight to discuss the budget for next year.  And before I begin my comments on it, I just want to say how much I appreciate all of the work that has gone into preparing this document. It is truly impressive. The first thing I wanted to do was make sure there were no furloughs for teachers because they have had them so many times over the years. So if we can avoid those at least one more time then let's try to do that. What I did not find in here though - and I know we talked about some things last week - but what I didn't find anywhere was any mention of the teacher supply fund. That money comes from the state every year. We get $25 per student for supplies. This past year we got around $250,000. Now I don't remember seeing anything in the budget where that money gets allocated out. Does anybody know what happens with that money? Because if we're going to talk about being transparent, we need to show people exactly where that money goes. If it's staying within central office then fine, tell us that. But if it's getting pushed down to schools, which I hope it does, then please break

Are there certain curriculum standards that require additional support from teachers? Is there an area where students have been consistently struggling?  I also noticed that the budget includes another 200 grand for technology infrastructure upgrades. Again, I'm all for staying current with tech advancements but can someone walk me through exactly which systems need updating and whether those updates align with long-term goals set forth by district administrators? What kind of return on investment do we expect from such expenditures? Finally, I feel strongly about increasing resources dedicated to mental health services within schools. jonnoalcaro.monologue: Our spotlight on education is a two-part spotlight tonight. So I'm gonna do two different introductions. It's my honor to first introduce two of our students and one of our learning coaches for their extraordinary personal achievements this year. Our students are champions. having earned this distinction last month at our division's annual Spelling Bee. This year, there were two separate competitions, one for our elementary school students and one for our middle schoolers. Lila Theed, a Mountain View fifth grader, finished first among the Spelling Bee winners from all of our elementary schools. And Henry Matthews from Henley placed first among all of our middle school winners. Both Lila and Henry will be competing in the Regional Spelling Bee, the next leg to the National Spelling Bee, which takes place this Saturday morning, beginning at 930 at Albemarle High School. We will also be represented by the second and third place finishers at each level. They include Claire Meng from Hollymead, Madeline Rasmussen from Red Hill, Catriona Shuev from Burling and Seven Gray from Lakeside. Also with us this evening are Katrina Sims and Kim Gibson, two of our lead coaches who serve as coordinators for this year's Bee. Please join me in thanking them and in congratulating Lila and Henry and all who participated in this year's program. I'd like to ask Katrina to formally introduce us to our two champions this evening. Ms. Sims.

jonnoalcaro.monologue: Thank you, Ms. Simmons. The second category is Equity in Education Month. The Virginia School Board Association tells us on their website that when inequity in education persists, there is a cost to all involved, including missed opportunities for economic development, greater dependence on government supports, and fewer Virginians ready to serve and lead. If every student is to fulfill their highest potential, and if the future of our communities is to be both personally rewarding and prosperous, the contributions of our public schools is vital. It is this truth that led the State Board Association to designate March as Equity in Education Month. Tonight we have with us Mary Morales, who is a Spanish teacher in Mountain View's immersion program, serves on the front line of our efforts to institutionalize classroom equity. Mary's story is an unusual one among teachers who have entered our culturally responsive teaching program. She has been a teacher for more than 30 years and more than 20 of those years have been here in our division. Her experience illustrates how this program is changing outcomes for students and for teachers by closing opportunity and achievement gaps. Ms. Morales, I'm hoping that you will bring to life for us tonight some of your insight as to how words about equity translate into better lives for students. Welcome.

jonnoalcaro:
model_responses: I believe that equity is when all learners have equal opportunities for success regardless of their race, ethnicity, gender identity, sexual orientation, or any other aspect of who they are.  And it's not just about giving them an opportunity; it's also providing them with resources so that they can actually take advantage of those opportunities.  So as we move forward, if there was one thing that I could say from my heart that would make me feel like this year had been successful, it would be if every single student felt seen, heard, valued, and loved within these walls because that's what matters most.

I would say that equity is not just about equality but it's also about justice, so we have to make sure everyone gets what they need. And as far as culturally responsive teaching goes, one thing I've learned through this program was the importance of understanding my own biases first because if I don't know where I stand then how can I teach them anything else? So, once I started doing some reflection on myself like learning more about microaggressions or implicit bias which are things that even though people might not intend harm still cause damage anyway. Once I realized these were part of me too, I could start working with kids who had different backgrounds than mine better. Now when I see something happen between two students from different racial groups, instead of ignoring it hoping it resolves itself, now I'm able to address those situations head-on and help both parties understand each other's perspectives. It changed everything for me and I believe it made an impact on their lives since they felt seen and heard throughout all of it.

I believe that equity in education month is an opportunity for us as educators, administrators, policymakers, parents, community members, and students to come together and acknowledge the systemic barriers that have been erected over time that prevent certain groups from having access to quality educational experiences.  It's not just about equality; it's about understanding that there are different starting points based on race, gender identity, socioeconomic status, ability, language proficiency, and so forth.  It means creating learning environments where all students feel seen, heard, valued, supported, challenged, and loved regardless of their backgrounds or identities. The Culturally Responsive Teaching Program was instrumental in my growth as an educator because it helped me understand that culture isn't something we do once a year during Black History Month or Hispanic Heritage Month but rather something that permeates every aspect of who we are, what we teach, and how we interact with each other. As a result, I've made significant changes to my practice. For instance, I now incorporate more diverse texts, images, and perspectives into my lessons to reflect the richness and complexity of human experiences. This shift helps create spaces where historically marginalized voices can speak back to dominant narratives, fostering empathy and critical thinking skills among my students. Moreover, this training empowered

jonnoalcaro:
model_responses: Thank you for asking this very timely and important question. As I consider whether to lift the masking requirement in our schools, my primary concern is always going to be student safety and well-being. model_responses: I'm so glad you brought this up, because we've had some great conversations about it already as an administration team, but also with the community through our strategic planning process last year. So first of all, let me just say that I believe very strongly that we have to take action around climate change right now. We can't wait for someone else to do something or put it off until later. It's one of those issues where every single day counts, and if there is anything we can do locally within these walls to make sure we're doing what we need to do to mitigate its effects, then we should absolutely be taking advantage of those opportunities.  One thing I know has come out of our strategic plan was looking at energy efficiency improvements throughout our buildings. And I would love to see us explore solar panels. There are grants available, which means they might not even cost us much money upfront. But having said that, I don't want to focus solely on the financial aspect either. Because again, when we talk about climate change, I truly believe this is a moral obligation for us as leaders and educators. So, I mean, it's something that is very important to me personally as well as professionally. But another piece of that, which you know gets back into the mental health stuff, but also just kind of the overall student experience, is thinking about what does it look like for us to create an environment where kids feel safe, they feel supported, they feel seen, heard, valued.  The whole list goes on.  One thing that came up recently with some parent feedback from the last year was around making sure that we've got recycling programs going strong within all of our buildings.  It sounds simple, but if kids can't even recycle their water bottles properly, then maybe we need to rethink that process.

I'm so glad that you brought this up, because it's something that we've been talking about quite a bit as a district.  You know, when I was running for the school board last year, one of my main campaign promises was to really focus on environmental sustainability within our district, not just from an educational standpoint but also operationally speaking. And I feel like there's such potential here, especially given how much energy consumption is happening in these buildings every day. So let me give you some ideas real quick. First off, with all due respect to our facilities team, they're doing their best, right now. But what would happen if we could actually hire someone who had expertise around green infrastructure or sustainable practices to help guide those decisions going forward? Because sometimes, yes, things can seem cost-prohibitive upfront. However, long-term savings might end up being significant. Another thing is potentially having solar panels installed at different locations throughout the district. We have a lot of big roofs out there where we could generate electricity. That seems pretty straightforward. A third idea -and maybe even more important than anything else- is incorporating green education into our curriculum across grade levels. What does it mean to live sustainably in today's world?

On the other hand, I understand the importance of ensuring safety in our schools. A police officer can provide valuable expertise in crisis situations and help maintain order when necessary. ellenosborne.monologue: Yes, I have a resolution. So whereas this past year, in the words of our state of the division report has been a year like any other filled with challenges and opportunities not easily imagined in February of 2020. And whereas the events and decisions of the past year have made the business of our school board, more complicated and consequential for the health of our students and staff into their academic, social and emotional well being. And whereas during this highly volatile Tom the board's connection to students, staff and families became even stronger as the number of opinions and insight offered to the board through emails and messages multiplied as much as 100 fold. as the number of participants at board meetings increased to thousands, as public comment was made more accessible, significantly increasing the number of speakers able to interact with board members, and whereas the transition from in-person to virtual meetings continues to present unplanned management duties, the fulfillment of which are crucial to the effective and responsive functioning of the board, And whereas during this period of time, one constant has been Ms. Jennifer Johnston, who this year was appointed for the 20th consecutive year to serve as a clerk of the board. And whereas Ms. Johnston has performed the new requirements presented by the pandemic while executing the board's priority to expand community engagement, and while also fulfilling her already considerable legal duties as board clerk. And whereas each year, Virginia School Board Association designates one week in February to build awareness of the role board clerks play in assisting school board members, superintendents, and our local schools. And whereas the association reminds us of how especially important this constant awareness is this year when Mrs. Johnston has been so instrumental to our success as we have managed through the barrage of changes resulting from the pandemic. Now therefore be it resolved that the Albemarle County School Board publicly expresses its deepest appreciation to Ms. Jennifer Johnston for her exceptional service and support of our work and therefore of the thousands of student and staff members we serve. And we call upon all constituents to join with us in recognizing Ms. Johnston's invaluable contributions to public education in Albemarle County and to join us in thanking her for two decades of outstanding service as the clerk of the Albemarle County School Board. Thank you.

ellenosborne.monologue: Yes, thank you. So we have a resolution. I'm going to read it now. It's in regard to the Child Nutrition Services. Whereas on Friday, March 13, Virginia Governor Ralph Northam ordered the closing of all schools in the Commonwealth for a period of two weeks to protect against the spread of the coronavirus. And whereas this action to protect public health through the closure of schools meant that students who participated in the federal government's free and reduced lunch program lost their access to the nutritious meals provided each day at school and Whereas in Albemarle County Public Schools, thousands of students were negatively impacted by this loss of access. And whereas among the school division's four values is its young people, specifically their academic and personal development, their health and well-being, And whereas in response to the closure of schools, the division's child nutrition department immediately began to plan to meet the needs of all children for healthy breakfast and lunches on a daily basis. And whereas within one business day of the governor's closure announcement, Child Nutrition Team members, under the guidance of Director Christina Pitzenberger, had organized a food distribution program. And whereas the program began with six school sites throughout the county, serving more than 1,000 meals a day to students and their siblings 18 years of old and younger. And whereas on March 23rd, The governor extended the closure of all K-12 schools in the Commonwealth through the end of the current academic year, and whereas the Child Nutrition Office continued to monitor the need among its students and all communities across the county for healthy meals and to work with the Department of Transportation in setting up additional food distribution sites, And whereas, as the result of this ongoing planning and teamwork, the office now distributes breakfast and lunches to students in 21 locations at schools and communities. And whereas, since March 17th, the Child Nutrition Office has provided more than 30,000 meals to students from all schools and locations in the county, and is continuing to evaluate the needs to further expand this service. Now therefore be it resolved that the Albemarle County School Board expresses its deep appreciation to Ms. Pitsenberger and her highly dedicated and skilled team for their invaluable support in meeting the nutritional and health needs of thousands of Albemarle County public school students and their siblings, and for doing so through such an expeditious and increasingly inclusive plan. And be it further resolved, the school board also salutes the contributions of the transportation department, its director James Foley, and his team for enabling the food distribution program to bring its services directly to the neighborhoods where students reside, thereby expanding participation in this vitally beneficial program. Thank you.

davidoberg.monologue: I'd like to just share that, I mean, we had 20 some people testify today. Anyone who's watching this online needs to understand the board has literally been receiving about 30 emails an hour for about two weeks now. And to the extent that we don't immediately reply, I can tell you that it's not intentional. It's simply because it's just so overwhelming how many people, but we are reading every single one of your emails. It does really matter to us. I make a point of replying to any student who directly emails me just because I've prioritized those. But I want you to know that I read every single email I receive. Even if I don't necessarily immediately respond to you, I hear you. I've heard a number of our teachers talking about the fact that it's hard on morale, that they're not feeling appreciated, that they're not feeling listened to. And this may be worthless to say, but I hope that you hear me. that our educators, all of us, not just our teachers, but our classified staff, our bus drivers, all the people who are assisting our children. We greatly appreciate, I appreciate not as a school board member, as a parent, everything you're doing for our students. We have an amazing staff. I'm supporting going forward on the 15th because my reading of the science indicates that seven days after your first shot, you are effectively inoculated. They don't have as great an inoculation if you receive your second shot. But with the Moderna vaccine, which most of our employees are receiving, it's 85%. And a competent inoculation is considered 50%. So without the second vaccination, you're already, you would be considered vaccinated under most vaccination systems. The reason I support waiting is because I think that, I think we owe it to our teachers for the, for the, for the people who've not yet gotten an appointment. We owe it to them to give them that chance to get an appointment. I just, and so I, you know, I hear you, Katrina and John, I hear you. I want, I want the kids back as soon as possible. I do, because I think we owe it to our children. There are some issues we're going to be dealing with this for, for probably 15 or 20 years, we're gonna be dealing with the ramifications of this for our children. But I also think that it's important to at least give to our employees that confidence to the extent that it helps that look, you've had your first shot, you're gonna get your second shot and we're gonna get through this. So I'll be voting yes. And I kind of think that everyone is gonna be mad at the solution I suspect that I suspect this is not going to make anybody happy, which kind of tells me it's probably the right one.

davidoberg.monologue: This is by far the hardest thing that we've dealt with in my five years on the board. There is just no, there is no good answer to any of this. Um, we've received literally thousands of emails and every one of them has a perspective that matters. I mean, it's just, you know, it's sort of, I mean, we have people saying absolutely open the schools immediately. We have people saying, don't open the schools ever and They all have good basis for their positions. I mean, this is a this is a tough, tough situation. So I just want to say I really appreciate all the work staff has put into this. And I really do, because, I mean, it is. I think the level of the level of effort that has gone in is kind of amazing. I am sort of in between a one and a two. All things being equal, I would be in one because I am a fairly risk-averse person. But I think we do have to listen to the voices of our teachers. who are saying they're going to lose some of the students who are English language learners, and our parents and our teachers of special education. And I've spoken to a number of them who've said, look, my child's not going to be able to do this at home. And I said this once before, but I'll reiterate it. I think that there's an argument to be made for all of our students that if they want it and their family wants it, that we ought to be prepared to give people a red shirt year. That they can redo the year because this pandemic will not last forever. We will get through this and past it. And it may simply be that some of the children don't receive everything they need this year. I think we need to be prepared as a board to give that offer to the family to say, hey, look, if you didn't get third grade, there is no stigma in any way, shape, or form to say, hey, you know what? Let's redo third grade and make sure you get everything you need before we advance you. But all that being said, I trust Dr. Haas. I trust his staff. Dr. Haas is recommending that we start it too. I absolutely have faith in him that he'll do that correctly and that If we need to, you know, my big concern is that when UVA reopens in about three weeks after the kids get here, we might have a real problem as a community. And I believe Dr. Haas's assurance is that if, hey, if the numbers go south, we close immediately. And with that provision, I will be supporting the motion.

davidoberg.monologue: There's also, and I'm sure you guys have looked at it, but I just want to make sure there's, and it hasn't been resolved at this point, but there's an argument to be made. that OSHA permits an employee from not coming to work based upon a justifiable fear of injury or death of an unsafe condition at work. It is unclear at this point, from my perspective, whether an individual, and I err on the side of caution, an individual with a justifiable, reasonable, and articulated concern regarding the safety of the work environment is protected from any sort of job action. grahampaige.monologue: County School Board to order. For our moment of silence, we'd like to have a special remembrance of one of our teachers who passed recently. Powerful ideas sometimes are described as throwing a rock in a river and watching it generate huge ripples that keep getting larger until they encompass a large area. This analogy can fit people as well as ideas. And so it was with Pete Fittner. To give you a sense of the length of his service, he was hired by Joe Vining to teach at Brownsville right out of ed school. In those days, Brownsville had 180 students. Pete also supported math students at Aetna Hurt and Woodbrook, and taught at Burleigh, where he received our community's highest award for teaching, the Golden Apple. His principal, Cassandra Blount, called him a trifecta as a teacher. She described his three superpowers as always building confidence in his students, treating students in a way that makes them want to reach their highest expectations, and he was so skilled in his methods that he could easily adapt to any student's need. He was known at Burleigh as King of the Dungeon, referring to the sixth grade's location on the basement level floor of the school. When you help kids begin to find their place in the world, Pete once said, you begin to find yourself too. Once you embrace who you are, the more you can give to help the students. If you are doing it right, the kids help you through the day. They help you as much as you help them. I want my students to fight for themselves and what they believe in was one of Pete's favorite thoughts. I tell them fight for you and fight for what you want. No matter what happens, you have to keep moving forward. You have to keep fighting. Pete's wife, Nancy, who teaches at Brownsville, said he kept doing that right up until this week. And Pete passed yesterday afternoon. Our condolences and our gratitude go out to the Fittner family. And the next time we see a ripple in that water, we will think of Pete and all the lives that he lifted up. We will now have a moment of silence. This meeting being conducted electronically, we have to read this into our minutes for each meeting. The minutes of this meeting should reflect that this meeting is being held electronically, pursuant to Virginia state law and Albemarle County ordinance, because the COVID-19 pandemic makes it impracticable and unsafe to assemble a quorum physically in a single location. The meeting is being communicated to the public electronically through Zoom and streamed live on the Albemarle County Public Schools website. And public comment may be offered through the Zoom waiting room feature in accordance with the school board's protocol or by written submission. And now to introduce our board members, Dr. Kate Acuff,

grahampaige.monologue: And I'm Graham Page, Samuel Miller district. a brief intro for our meeting this afternoon. Since March of 2020, Albemarle County Public Schools have faced unprecedented challenges in accomplishing its mission of establishing a community of learners and learning through relationships, relevance, and rigor, one student at a time. Our students, staff, and families have adapted to these challenges and changes with creativity, flexibility, and perseverance. Our teachers have continued to provide our students with a world-class education virtually. Our students have worked to master new skills on new learning platforms. Our families have helped to facilitate their children's virtual learning, becoming tech troubleshooters and tutors in addition to maintaining their normal day jobs. We remain grateful to them and proud of them for continuing their great work under difficult circumstances. While managing education amidst the uncertainties of a pandemic, Albemarle County Public Schools have simultaneously fought in the battle to end the predictive value of race and ensure the success of each individual student and staff member during a period of social unrest in our community and society. We have worked to eliminate the opportunity gap that exists in our division so that we can eradicate it and build a system that works for everyone in our strong and diverse community of learners. This work will help us all learn to understand difference and respect and champion the diverse life experiences of all members of our community. We are so grateful to the Virginia General Assembly for its support for public education both over the years, and doing the 2020 special session. We have seen how you make public education, a large part of the conversations that you have around legislation and funding. We know that you have made schools a priority during the pandemic crisis, and we have worked to do our part in keeping keeping our county public school community strong as we push through this unusual moment in time. A lot is being done to keep our county families strong. Our transportation and child nutrition departments have taken advantage of an FDA waiver that allows the county schools to deliver meals to our students. Every day, 7,000 meals are delivered to over 3,500 students by 62 buses. This ensures that our students have nutritious meals and an opportunity to engage with their schools. We've established a COVID-19 hotline that would allow us to provide any available resources to those in need during the pandemic. We're also expanding our mental health services, including training members of our staff in mental health first aid, so that we can help lift the emotional burden that COVID has caused in our community. Our extended day enrichment program mobilized to create a child care program for county employees, public school employees. Currently, there are more than 40 students enrolled in this program, and we are extending it as we further hope our school doors open to accommodate more of our employees. Over 1,000 hotspots have been provided to our students and employees in order to facilitate virtual learning for those who do not have reliable internet. These were provided at no cost to recipients. Our anti-racism policy steering committee has implemented a book study on Glenn Singleton's courageous conversations about race for our school board and leadership team members. This work will help us ensure that our educators can help the division eliminate the predictive value of race in our school division. Our four items in our 2021 legislative packet is aligned with all of these programs and with the work our division is doing. My colleagues will now speak on the subject of each of these four. We'll start with Mr. Alcaro, who will lead the discussion on social justice. Mr. Alcaro.

grahampaige.monologue: Thank you, Miss Collins. But this is the governor's proclamation, where school principals work cooperatively to direct, develop, and inspire all members of the school staff and student body, and to communicate effectively with parents to engage them in the learning process. And whereas principals serve as educational leaders responsible for managing the policies, regulations and procedures necessary to ensure a safe and effective learning environment for all students in Virginia's public and private schools. And whereas principals and teachers are entrusted with the opportunity and the responsibility of guiding, directing, nurturing, mentoring, and imparting knowledge to our children while they are at school. And whereas principals must work collaboratively with teachers, staff, students, parents, and the community at large to proactively prepare students to be self-reliant and productive citizens. and whereas Virginia School Principals Appreciation Week is an opportunity to recognize the hard work of Virginia schools principals and to recognize the importance of principals in ensuring that every child has access to a quality education. Now, therefore, I, Ralph S. Northam, do hereby recognize January the 8th through 14th, 2022 as Virginia School Principal Appreciation Week in our Commonwealth of Virginia. And I call this observance to the attention of all of our citizens. So we do congratulate and extend our appreciation to all of our principals. And again, we really are pleased to have at least four of our principals attending tonight.

grahampaige.monologue: Thank you. Sorry. Thank you for recognizing. Okay. Sorry that I overlooked you, Ms. Morris. Now moving to our spotlight on education. Tonight, we are truly honored to have with us Mrs. Lucille Smith, who recently completed unforgettable and extensive history of Jackson P. Burleigh High School. Last year, the school was added to the National Register of Historic Places. In her preface, Ms. Smith wrote, Black History Matters. We must continue to document and preserve the rich and brave story of African-American students in Charlottesville City and Atmau County. Before readers open the book's first pages, Ms. Smith advises them that the interviews from students, faculty, and administrators are raw, candid, and from the heart. Her connections to segregated education includes her husband Rizal, who graduated from Burleigh High School in 1966. Rizal later served as chair of the Charlottesville City School Board. Ms. Smith grew up and attended school in North Little Rock, Arkansas, across the river from Little Rock Central High School, a place forever known for its role in bringing into national public consciousness the struggle for racial educational opportunity. unforgettable, the history of Burleigh is not a volume though about separate and unequal education in our community. It is instead a joyous celebration of remarkable young men and women whose time at Burleigh comes back in pages filled with personal reflections, copies of original documents and photos, and a long list of extraordinary achievements. It recounts a story that should be told again and again of how education teaches us perseverance, pride, and confidence, friendship, and the value of just plain hard work, and how together all of these gifts build strong families and careers and selfless and uplifting community service. Although she did not have the opportunity to attend Burleigh, the considerable talents of Ms. Smith as a historian and writer would convince you otherwise. She served for more than 30 years with the U.S. Army National Ground Intelligence Center. She now devotes much of her time as a volunteer to local boards and community organizations and to her church. I understand that our school division will be making copies of Unforgettable available to all of our schools, to all of our school libraries. I'd like to formally introduce you to Lucille Smith and ask our guest to share with us some thoughts about her important contribution to learning for all students in our school division. Miss Smith, welcome.

We're actually regularly seeing much higher numbers of new cases in our health district than we have at any point during this pandemic, especially since July 4th, and that hasn't abated. judyle.monologue: Thank you, Chair Page. Whereas since 1972 National School Nurse Day has served to strengthen the understanding of how school nurses have contributed to the academic, social, and emotional development of students, and whereas this year during the most severe pandemic to occur in school communities in 100 years, school nurses have eagerly been frontline protectors of the public health, overseeing health strategies and practices that make school safe places for children, and whereas in gratitude for this service, National School Nurse Day and National School Nurses Week have been expanded to incorporate celebrations, the entire month of May. And whereas in Albemarle County Public Schools in recent years, visits by students and staff to school clinics have exceeded 180,000 or more than 140 visits each hour of every school day. And whereas in a given year, our school nurses record more than 14,000 treatments of students with chronic conditions. And this year, 17 of our school nurses are members of the emergency medical core and have administered COVID-19 vaccines to employees. And whereas school nurses often are the first and on occasion, the primary healthcare provider for families. And whereas the instant actions of school nurses in emergencies have saved lives, prevented more serious illness and injury, and contain the spread of infectious diseases in our schools, and whereas school nurses are invaluable connectors of the school community, families, and health care providers in promoting wellness and access to health care when a child's cognitive development is at its peak. Now, therefore, be it resolved that the Albemarle County School Board does hereby express and call upon all members of the school division and residents of the county to express deepest appreciation to all of our school nurses for their extraordinary and selfless devotion to public health and safety every year, and especially this year, and further resolve that a framed copy of this resolution be provided to every school nurse in the division this May 13th, 2021.

Firstly, I have a question about intervention services. And I know that you don't have those numbers ready, but that's something that I would like to know next week. Also, I would like to know how instructional hours for the hybrid learners will compare with the instructional hours of the virtual learners in K-3, or pre-K-3, I guess, for the four-day-a-week students. I assume that the 4-5, 4-12, I guess, would be the same. But I just would like to know the difference, if there is any difference between the instructional time for those youngest learners. And then on a different note, I don't know if this is something that Ross considers or we consider how this works. I know that we've all read a lot in the news about how the single cloth masks are just not as effective now against that. So that's just something I guess I'll throw out there.

judyle.monologue: Thank you, Chair Page. This resolution of the Board of Education of Albemarle County Virginia School Board adopting order number 21-3 of the Director of Emergency Management for the County of Albemarle, Virginia. Whereas the school board recognizes that Albemarle County and the rest of the state of Virginia and the United States are in the midst of a worldwide COVID-19 pandemic that has resulted in more than 600,000 deaths in the United States. And whereas the school board has responded to the challenges brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic, providing students and staff members with the technology and resources necessary to ensure the efficient delivery of instruction virtually and in person. And whereas the school board has a substantial public interest in protecting the health and safety of its students, staff and community, and ensuring that the school division can provide staff and students with a safe and effective educational environment that supports student achievement. And whereas school division staff at all levels are essential to the day-to-day operations of the school division and are responsible for the thorough and efficient education of all students and their social and emotional well-being. And whereas a surge of COVID-19 cases has recently occurred, largely resulting from the Delta variant, also known as B.1.617.2, a highly transmissible virus that impacts individuals regardless of age, And whereas over 90% of COVID-19 infections are currently occurring in individuals who have not been vaccinated against COVID-19. And whereas the overwhelming scientific evidence has established that the vaccines authorized by the FDA for emergency use are safe and effective. and recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for all individuals except children under 12 years of age and certain others, and whereas the school board has the responsibility to prevent the outbreak and spread of COVID-19 infections in its schools and other facilities, and whereas the Director of Emergency Management for the County of Albemarle, Virginia has issued Order Number 21-3 pursuant to Virginia Code 44-146.21c, mandating vaccines, vaccinations, or periodic testing for COVID-19 for the employees of the County of Albemarle. Now, therefore, be it resolved that the school board finds that there exists a public health emergency that requires action to safeguard students and staff against the risks of infection, illness, hospitalization, and death from COVID-19. The school board adopts order number 21 dash three and will work in partnership with the county of Albemarle in the implementation of this order to control the spread of coven 19 in the school division and community. The administration of the school division is directed to develop procedures for the implementation of this resolution that are based upon order number 21-2 as modified to reflect the specific operations of the school division and school board policies, regulations, and code of conduct, and otherwise take all other actions necessary to carry out this mandate. The school board hereby delegates to the superintendent the authority to implement and modify vaccination and testing procedures based on changing conditions and to maintain conformance with the requirements of the CDC, Virginia Department of Health, Blue Ridge Health District, and other applicable health authorities.

judyle.monologue: Thank you, Chair Page. We just observed National Women's History Month here in the United States. One of its purposes was to join in commemorating and encouraging the study, observance, and celebration of the vital role women play in American history. Earlier this week, we received an advanced look at just who we will be celebrating in future years, and four of these extraordinary young women, I'm proud to say, are our students. The annual Emily Couric Leadership Forum Scholarship Awards were announced this week, and in the words of the forum, their awards are designed to encourage all women to adopt an active role in government, public issues, and policy debates affecting their communities, and to inspire young women to pursue activities that will empower them to become effective leaders. For the second consecutive year, the top award, the Emily Couric Leadership Scholarship, was earned by an Albemarle High School student, and this year she's Aditi Prakash. Aditi plans a career in education policy, especially to help bring the love of science to disadvantaged students. She will receive $35,000 toward her college education at Stanford University. The recipient of the forum's Joshua J. Scott Merit Award and a $15,000 scholarship is Rachel Field from Monticello High School. Of course, we all remember Rachel's medical research project from her appearance before us last month. Two other students received $7,000 scholarships from the forum, Mia Shiner from our charter school and Kimball Sheehan from Western Albemarle High School. Aditi and Rachel were able to join us this evening and under normal circumstances, I would ask them to join us at the podium so that we could shake their hands. In this virtual world, however, I wonder if we could all applaud and give a thumbs up to these extraordinary young women and tell them that we all are looking forward to reading about their impressive accomplishments in future years.

judyle.monologue: Thank you, Chair Page. Last month, we had the wonderful opportunity to hear from Baker Butler educators about the nationally recognized gains they have made in closing the achievement gap at their school. Tonight we're focusing on yet another opportunity gap in our schools and in schools across our nation, the percentage of students of color who enter STEM related fields. 45 years ago, an organization was established to address this issue, the National Society of Black Engineers. Its mission was ambitious and vital to the collective prosperity of every community in the United States. The society was organized to promote academic excellence, provide scholarships, train leaders, and expand access to professional careers. A few years ago, the society broadened its charter to include high school chapters, and one of the first chapters in Central Virginia was established at Albemarle High School. Membership is open to students from all of our middle school and high schools, regardless of race or ethnicity. Students from Greer, Burley, and soon Walton are members and students are members, and students from UVA serve as mentors. There currently are 25 students in our local chapter, and more than 100 students have had their lives changed by this extraordinary program. Many have gone on to earn engineering degrees at the university level. The driving, guiding, determined light for these young people continues to be Ms. Pearl Early, Albemarle High School student support specialist. A characteristic of this program is its strong emphasis on project-based learning. Students learn how to research, design, experiment with, and refine solutions that can improve our lives. A natural topic this year is COVID-19, and true to form, students have come up with an ingenious approach to protecting public health. I understand that the nature of this development process is that it can take up to two years, but our students have field-tested their invention within seven months.
